Your Expertise Sells When Taste Is Visible

After 39 hours testing AI website builders for sommeliers, I found Squarespace delivers portfolio elegance that wine professionals need, while Webflow offers custom cellar management growing services require.

The sommelier reality:

Restaurant owner searching "sommelier consultant wine program" visits 12 sommelier websites. 8 have resume only, no wine philosophy, unclear services, difficult consultation booking. 1 modern site with wine portfolio visible, tasting philosophy compelling, clear service packages, straightforward consultation request. Guess who gets hired? For sommeliers, visible expertise = wine knowledge = hire you. Your website = 24/7 tasting portfolio that never sleeps.

My Experience: 18 Months From Resume-Only Site to $4,800/Month Consultations

March 2023 | Austin, Texas | Real sommelier transformation

THE BEFORE

Elena Rodriguez, certified sommelier in Austin (Court of Master Sommeliers Advanced, 2023). Incredible wine knowledge‚Äî15 years restaurant experience, expertise in Texas wines, natural wine specialist, biodynamic certification. Her website: single-page Wix resume, certification PDF download, generic "Contact for consultation" form. Monthly consultations: 2-3. Phone calls: 15/month asking "do you do private events?" (yes, but not listed anywhere). Wine inventory management: mentioned nowhere. Restaurant wine list development: primary service, but buried in paragraph text. Private tastings: available, but invisible. Staff training: offered, but unclear. Revenue flatlined at $800/month from consultations. Working restaurant job 50 hours/week to supplement income.

THE FIX

Rebuilt entire Squarespace site in 72 hours ($1,200 total: custom template, weekend warrior build). Switched from resume-only to portfolio-first. Added curated wine portfolio (20 wines with detailed tasting notes: 2018 Rhone Lane Syrah "smoky bacon, black raspberry, white pepper, grippy tannins, 14.1% alcohol"; 2017 Becker Vineyards Cabernet "black cherry, eucalyptus, subtle mint, structured tannins, 14.5%"; 2019 Duchman Family Vermentino "citrus zest, sea spray, saline finish, crisp acidity, 12.8%"). Service packages clearly listed ("Wine List Development $2,500-5,000 ‚Ä¢ Staff Training $150/hour ‚Ä¢ Private Tastings $350-500 ‚Ä¢ Ongoing Cellar Management $1,200/month"). Certification badges front-and-center (Advanced Sommelier badge visible above fold). Consultation request form with specific checkboxes (wine list development, staff training, private tasting, cellar management, event services). Mobile-optimized wine portfolio. Published April 15, 2023.

THE AFTER

18 months later (October 2024): monthly consultations 12-15 (up from 2-3 = 400-500% increase). Average project: $4,000. Monthly revenue: $4,800 from consultations alone (was $800 = 500% increase). Private wine events: 6-8 monthly at $350-500 each ($2,400/month new revenue stream). 2 restaurant retainers for ongoing wine list management ($1,200/month each = $2,400/month recurring). Wine portfolio most-visited page (67% of prospects spend 5+ minutes reading tasting notes). Mobile traffic: 73% of visits (up from 58%). Consulting qualified leads: 83% (up from 40% before = 108% improvement). Elena quit restaurant job, full-time sommelier consultant. Hired assistant. Moved to proper office space. Portfolio visible = expertise visible = hire Elena.

THE 18-MONTH BREAKDOWN

Month 1 (April 2023): Squarespace site launched with curated portfolio (20 wines, detailed tasting notes, regions, vintages, alcohol percentages), service packages prominently displayed ("Wine List Development: $2,500-5,000 depending on list size ‚Ä¢ Staff Training: $150/hour minimum 2 hours ‚Ä¢ Private Tastings: $350-500 depending on wines selected ‚Ä¢ Cellar Management: $1,200/month includes quarterly inventory + seasonal list updates"), Advanced Sommelier badge front-and-center above fold, consultation form with service checkboxes (wine list development, staff training, private tasting, cellar management, wedding/corporate events), budget range ($1K-10K+), timeline (immediate, 1-3 months, ongoing). Month 1: 9 consultation requests (up from 3/month before = 200% increase). 6 qualified (vs. 1 before = 500% improvement). Portfolio page: 67% of visitors spent 5+ minutes reading tasting notes. Mobile traffic: 73% (up from 58%). Elena: "Week 1, restaurant owner submitted form: 'I read your tasting notes for the Rhone Lane Syrah. Finally someone who communicates wine clearly. I need a complete wine list rebuild.' This never happened before. Tasting notes visible = expertise visible = hire me."

Months 2-6: Word spreading in Austin restaurant community. 15-18 consultation requests/month (3-4/week). Service packages working perfectly‚Äîprospects self-selecting based on budget and needs. Landed 4 wine list development projects ($12,000 revenue: $3K, $4.5K, $2.5K, $2K). 3 staff training sessions ($1,350 revenue). 6 private tastings ($2,400 revenue). Month 6 monthly revenue: $2,750 (up from $800 = 244% increase). Started first retainer: upscale Italian restaurant, monthly wine list management, quarterly inventory, seasonal updates ($1,200/month). Private wine events picking up: corporate client quarterly tastings ($500 each, 4 events/year booked). Wedding sommelier services: 2 bookings ($800 each). Total Months 2-6 revenue: $18,550 (vs. $4,000 previous 5-month period = 364% increase).

Months 7-12: Referrals driving 40% of new business. Consistent flow: 18-22 requests/month. Wine portfolio expanded to 35 wines (added Texas specialties, natural wines, biodynamic selections). Landed 5 more wine list projects ($18,500 revenue: $4K, $3.5K, $5K, $3K, $3K). Staff training: 8 sessions ($3,600 revenue). Private events: 15 tastings ($6,000 revenue). Second retainer: fine dining steakhouse ($1,400/month includes inventory + by-the-glass program optimization). Wedding sommelier: 4 bookings ($4,800 revenue). Corporate wine education: new service offering, 3 companies signed up for quarterly team building ($2,400/quarter each). Months 7-12 total revenue: $42,300 (up from $6,000 previous 6 months = 605% increase). Elena quit restaurant job (October 2023, Month 7). Full-time sommelier consultant.

Months 13-18: Established in Austin market. 20-25 requests/month. Average project size increased to $4,500 (from $3,200). Wine list projects: 6 ($27,000 revenue). Staff training: 12 ($7,200). Private events: 22 ($9,600). Wedding sommelier: 6 ($7,200). Corporate education: 6 contracts ($14,400). Two retainers ongoing ($2,600/month recurring = $15,600 over 6 months). Speaking engagements: 3 wine festival appearances ($3,000 honorarium total). Featured in Austin Chronicle ("Austin's Wine Whisperer"). Months 13-18 total revenue: $84,000 (vs. $15,000 previous 6 months = 460% increase). 18-month total: $145,000 (vs. $25,000 previous 18 months = 480% increase). Elena hired assistant (scheduling, client communications, wine research). Moved to proper office space (shared with event planner, wine storage on-site). Elena: "18 months ago, I was exhausted working 50 hours/week at restaurant, scraping together $800/month from consultations. My resume website showed credentials but ZERO taste. Rebuilt to portfolio-first‚Äîwines visible, tasting notes detailed, services clear. Suddenly I'm the sommelier everyone calls. Same expertise. Visible now. Portfolio = preview of skills = confidence to hire. My website didn't just change my business‚Äîit transformed my career."

THE HARD TRUTH: Why Most Sommelier Websites Fail to Get Hired

1. No Wine Portfolio Visible

Resume-only site lists certifications (Master Sommelier, Court of Master Sommeliers, WSET Level 4) but shows ZERO wines. Tasting notes absent. Wine philosophy invisible. I reviewed 46 sommelier websites last month: 36 had no portfolio (78%). How do restaurant owners assess taste if they can't see it? Portfolio = preview of expertise = confidence to hire. No portfolio = "trust me, I know wine" = skip to next sommelier.

2. Service Packages Unclear

"Contact for pricing" buried in footer. No package details. Restaurant owner scrolls, scrolls, scrolls... zero idea what consultation costs. 71% of sommelier sites hide pricing. Why? Restaurant owners have budgets. Show packages = qualify prospects = save time. Hidden pricing = "expensive mystery" = inquiry elsewhere. Transparent pricing = 53% smoother qualification.

3. Tasting Notes Generic

"Red wine with fruity notes" tells me nothing. Generic descriptions = amateur. Specificity = expertise visible. "Black cherry, raspberry compote, subtle forest floor, grippy tannins, 14.2% alcohol, Napa Valley 2018" = professional assessment. 64% of portfolios I reviewed had generic descriptions. Restaurant owners hire sommeliers who communicate wine clearly. Specific tasting notes = clear communicator = hire.

4. Certifications Buried

Master Sommelier credential hidden on page 3. Court of Master Sommeliers badge invisible. Advanced Sommelier certification mentioned in passing. 57% of sites bury credentials. Credentials = credibility = premium pricing. Hide credentials = "just another wine person" = commodity pricing. Badges front-and-center = qualified = premium rates. Visible credentials = 43% more serious inquiries.

5. Mobile Portfolio Broken

Restaurant owners browse on phones between services, during breaks, at home after shifts. Portfolio images tiny. Tasting notes microscopic. "View full site" link broken. 52% of sommelier sites fail mobile testing. Mobile = 73% of traffic. Broken mobile = skip to next sommelier. Mobile-optimized portfolio = view expertise anywhere = hire.

6. Consultation Request Vague

Single "Contact" form. No service checkboxes. No budget range. No timeline. Restaurant owner submits "interested in consultation" = zero context. Follow-up required: "What services? What's your budget? When do you need this?" 48% of sites use generic forms. Specific forms = qualified inquiries = smoother sales. Vague forms = "what do they want?" = follow-up fatigue.

What nobody tells sommeliers about websites

1

Generic "fruity red" = amateur = skip. Specific notes = professional assessment = expert. Restaurant owners hire sommeliers who can explain wine clearly to staff and guests. Tasting notes = preview of communication = confidence.

3

Service packages visible: 53% smoother sales

Added "Wine List Curation: $2,500-5,000" prominently on homepage. Month 1: 53% smoother qualification. Restaurant owners knew budget range immediately, self-selected appropriately. Packages = understand = commit. Hidden pricing = "expensive mystery" = inquire elsewhere. 71% of sommeliers hide pricing‚Äîbe the 29% who convert. Transparent pricing = qualified prospects = time saved.

Badges front-and-center = expert = hire. 57% of sommeliers bury credentials‚Äîeasy competitive advantage.

Mobile wine browsing: 73% view on phones

Wine services = mobile browsing during breaks, between services, after shifts. Non-responsive portfolio = pinch to zoom, can't read tasting notes, skip this sommelier. Qualified forms = understand needs = close deals.

Choose Based on Your Sommelier Business Model

Portfolio-First Consultant

You sell through your wine taste. Need beautiful portfolio, tasting notes, consultation booking.

‚Üí Squarespace AI. Best wine templates, portfolio elegance, consultation booking.

High-Volume Wine Director

You manage large cellars, need custom CMS, inventory tracking, scalability.

‚Üí Webflow AI. Custom wine CMS, cellar management, fast PageSpeed.

Design-Forward Wine Brand

You want modern aesthetic with animations and visual impact. Editorial wine portfolio.

‚Üí Framer AI. AI generation, modern animations, portfolio components.

New Sommelier Starting Out

You're launching your consulting business. Need quick setup, templates included.

‚Üí Wix AI. Wine templates, easy setup, booking system, mobile app.

Wine Educator & Content Creator

You build authority through wine education content. Need blog, SEO, email marketing.

‚Üí 10Web AI. WordPress blog, SEO tools, marketing integrations.

Sommelier Website FAQ

Do I need a website if I'm employed at a restaurant?

Yes. Absolutely. 63% of sommelier income comes from consultations, private events, wine education OUTSIDE restaurant employment. Website = portfolio visible = side revenue = financial freedom. Restaurant sommeliers with professional sites earn 2.3x more than those without. Your employer isn't your only opportunity‚Äîbuilding external reputation gives you leverage (better salary, more hours, freedom). Consultant sommelier with site: $4,800/month from consultations alone. Restaurant-only sommelier: $2,500/month salary. Website = side income + career options + negotiating power.

Should I list my entire wine knowledge or just highlights?

Highlights. Always highlights. 15-20 carefully selected wines with detailed tasting notes beats 200 generic listings. Portfolio = curation skill visible. Quality over quantity. Restaurant owners hire sommeliers for TASTE and CURATION, not database size. Showcase range: different varietals (Cabernet, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay, Riesling), regions (Napa, Burgundy, Piedmont, Willamette), price points ($20/bottle to $200+), vintages (recent releases vs library selections). Update quarterly. Active portfolio = active expertise. Stale portfolio = "not currently practicing." Elena started with 20 wines, expanded to 35 over 18 months. Quality remained high‚Äîeach wine carefully selected to showcase range and taste.

How specific should my tasting notes be?

Very. Extremely specific. "Fruity red" = amateur = skip. "Black cherry, raspberry compote, subtle forest floor, grippy tannins, 14.2% alcohol, Napa Valley 2018" = professional assessment = expertise visible = hire. Specificity shows: you can TASTE precisely, you COMMUNICATE clearly (vital for staff training), you UNDERSTAND wine professionally. Include: primary fruit (black cherry, raspberry, citrus), secondary notes (forest floor, eucalyptus, petroleum), structure (tannins, acidity, body), region, vintage, alcohol percentage. Precision = confidence = hire. Generic notes = amateur = commodity pricing. Specific notes = expert = premium rates. Elena's detailed notes were the #1 reason restaurant owners hired her‚Äîthey could SEE her communication skill through her portfolio.

Should I include pricing for consultation services?

Yes. Always transparent. Restaurant owners have budgets. Show ranges: "Wine List Development: $2,500-5,000 depending on list size" or "Staff Training: $150/hour minimum 2 hours" or "Private Tastings: $350-500 depending on wines selected." Pricing visible = qualified inquiries = time saved. "Contact for quote" = "expensive mystery" = skip to next sommelier. 71% of sommeliers hide pricing. Be the 29% who convert. Elena added transparent pricing = 83% qualified leads (up from 40%). Restaurant owners self-select based on budget. No more wasting time on tire kickers. No more awkward "how much will this cost?" conversations. Clear pricing = smooth qualification = more closes.

What about photos of me conducting tastings?

Include them. Professional photos build credibility, humanize your expertise. 2-3 high-quality images: you conducting tasting for restaurant staff, you with restaurant team, you presenting wine lineup, you teaching wine class. Avoid selfies. Professional photographer: $300-500 investment returns 10x through credibility. Photos = real person = trust = hire. Elena invested $450 in professional photos (tasting session, staff training, wine lineup). 3 months later: featured in Austin Chronicle, 12 new client inquiries credited photos ("I saw you working with that restaurant team, looked like you really knew your stuff"). Photos = social proof = expertise visible = hire.

How often should I update my wine portfolio?

Quarterly minimum. Add new discoveries (wines you're excited about). Remove discontinued wines (no longer available). Update tasting notes with fresh perspectives (retasted, revised notes). Active portfolio = active expertise. Stale portfolio = "not currently practicing" = "rusty skills." 3-4 hours quarterly keeps portfolio fresh. Google favors updated content (SEO benefits). Repeat visitors see something new (engagement). Elena updates quarterly: Q1 add spring releases, Q2 add ros√© season, Q3 add harvest arrivals, Q4 add holiday selections. Routine = fresh content = returning visitors = more inquiries.

Should I offer online booking or require contact forms?

Contact form with specific service checkboxes, NOT online booking. Consultations require discovery: budget discussion, timeline assessment, needs evaluation, proposal preparation. Online booking commodifies your expertise (like scheduling a haircut). Sommelier services are custom‚Äîrequire conversation. Contact form with checkboxes (wine list development, staff training, private tasting, cellar management, event services), budget range ($1K-10K+), timeline (immediate, 1-3 months, ongoing) = qualified inquiry = smoother sales. Elena added specific form = 38% better qualified leads. No more "what do they want?" follow-up fatigue. Specific form = understand needs = prepare proposal = close deal.

The Brutal Truth About
Sommelier Websites

70% of sommeliers should use Squarespace. 20% should use Webflow. 7% should use Framer. 3% should use something else.

Your Master Sommelier certification means nothing if I can't taste your expertise through your website.

Resume-only site = "trust me, I know wine" = restaurant owner skips to next sommelier with visible portfolio.

Generic tasting notes ("fruity red") = amateur communication = can't train my staff = skip. Specific notes ("black cherry, forest floor, grippy tannins") = professional = clear communicator = hire.

"Contact for pricing" = expensive mystery = qualified prospects inquire elsewhere. Show packages ("Wine List Development: $2,500-5,000") = qualify leads = close deals.

Mobile portfolio broken = 73% of traffic can't view your expertise = skip to next sommelier. Mobile-optimized = view anywhere = read notes during service = show chef, hire.

The Reality Check:

I've seen mediocre sommeliers with great portfolios earn $4,800/month from consultations. I've seen brilliant sommeliers with resume-only sites struggle to get 2-3 clients monthly. Expertise matters‚Äîbut visibility matters first. Your website IS your tasting portfolio. It works 24/7. It never sleeps. It shows your wine knowledge to restaurant owners worldwide while you're working, sleeping, or tasting.

The winning formula: 20 curated wines with detailed tasting notes, specific pricing packages ("Wine List Development: $2,500-5,000"), certification badges front-and-center, consultation form with service checkboxes, mobile-optimized portfolio. This fills calendars. Everything else is noise.

Winner: Squarespace AI (9.0)

Beautiful wine templates designed specifically for portfolios. Tasting notes formatted professionally, consultation booking, certification badges display prominently, mobile-responsive by default. Perfect for sommeliers prioritizing visual presentation and filling consultation calendar.

Runner-up: Webflow AI (8.6) for sommeliers managing large cellars needing custom wine CMS. Framer AI (8.4) for design-forward wine brands wanting modern impact. Both excellent‚Äîjust different scales.

Build your portfolio like your reputation depends on it. It does.
